intro: Luzula comosa var. macrantha, commonly known as the tufted wood sedge, is a perennial plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and produces spike-like inflorescences with small, clustered flowers. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or wetland habitats. Its botanical features make it a valuable component of ecological systems, supporting various pollinators and soil stability.
